columns.text: In this problem, we will use Tobin's Q to solve for the book value and market value of the debt.

Substituting the values to the formula above, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tobin's Q}&=\dfrac{(20,000 \times \$58)+\$115,000}{\$552,811}\\[15 pt]
&=2.306
\end{aligned}$$

The Tobin's Q for this is $2.306$

Since the Tobin's Q value is greater than $1.0$, it can be concluded that the company's recorded assets are lower than the market value. 

This gives us an assumption that the book value and the market value of the debt are equal.

The book value and the market value of the debt are different because the book value looks at the debt that is recorded in the balance sheet while the market value debt is the price that the market is willing to pay for the firm's debt. 

This means that it is possible to substitute the book value of the debt in place of the market value if the market value is not available. The corresponding value will not be the same but the values will be close.
